sage.input

Class ThirdPersonCameraController

  • java.lang.Object
    • sage.input.ThirdPersonCameraController

  • public class ThirdPersonCameraController
extends java.lang.Object
    ThirdPersonCameraController defines an object which manages an "orbit camera"; that is, a third person camera which always looks at a given SceneNode, called the target, but which can be "orbited" around the target using an input controller such as a mouse or gamepad.

    In the case of a mouse, dragging the mouse with the left-button pressed orbits the camera around the target; dragging with the right button pressed both orbits the camera and changes the orientation of the target. Mouse x-drag changes the camera azimuth with respect to the target; mouse y-drag changes the elevation angle. The mouse wheel zooms the camera in/out on the target.

    In the case of a gamepad, buttons 5 and 6 (typically labeled LEFT or LB, and RIGHT or RB respectively, e.g. in the case of an XBox controller) perform functions equivalent to the left and right mouse buttons as described above; the RX axis (typically the right joystick) performs equivalently to the mouse X axis and the RY axis (again typically the right joystick) performs equivalently to the mouse Y axis. In other words, holding down LB while moving the right joystick left/right orbits the camera around the target while holding down RB while moving the right joystick left right both orbits the camera and changes the target orientation; moving the right joystick forward/backwards while holding down either LB or LT changes the camera elevation angle. The gamepad Z axis (typically the left and right trigger buttons (LT and LB) e.g. on an XBox controller) controls camera zoom in/out on the target.

    Both zoom and elevation angle are constrained to certain minimum/maximum values, which can be set by client code, as can the movement speed. By default the ThirdPersonCameraController sets the mouse cursor to be invisible.

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static float DEFAULT_MAX_CAMERA_ELEVATION_ANGLE
      The default value for the maximum camera elevation angle.
      static float DEFAULT_MAX_DISTANCE
      The default value for the maximum distance which the camera is allowed to be from the target.
      static float DEFAULT_MIN_CAMERA_ELEVATION_ANGLE
      The default value for the minimum camera elevation angle.
      static float DEFAULT_MIN_DISTANCE
      The default value for the minimum distance which the camera is allowed to be from the target node.
      static graphicslib3D.Vector3D DEFAULT_TARGET_OFFSET
      The default value for the offset from the target which determines the point at which the camera looks.
      static graphicslib3D.Vector3D DEFAULT_WORLD_UP_VECTOR
      The default value for the "world up" direction.

      Constructs a ThirdPersonCameraController that allows orbiting the specified camera around the specified target SceneNode using the controls provided by the specified IInputManager and input controller.

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ICamera getCamera()
      Returns the camera which this ThirdPersonCameraController is controlling.

      Returns the current distance between the camera and the target.

      Returns the current maximum distance which the camera is allowed to be moved away from the target SceneNode.

      Returns the current maximum elevation angle (in degrees) which the camera is allowed to rotate "above" the target.

      Returns the current minimum allowed distance between the camera and the target.
      float getMinElevationAngle()
      Returns the current minimum elevation angle (in degrees) for the camera.

      Returns the mouse "speed factor"; that is, the multiplier which is used to control the amount by which mouse changes cause changes in camera movement.

      Returns the SceneNode which is the current target of the camera (that is, the SceneNode that the camera looks at.

      Returns the target offset; that is, the offset amount in the world "up" direction above the target SceneNode which defines the point at which the camera looks.
      graphicslib3D.Point3D getTargetPos()
      Returns the position of the target (that is, the SceneNode which the camera being controlled looks at).

      Returns the direction of "up" in the world coordinate system.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ThirdPersonCameraController

        public ThirdPersonCameraController(ICamera cam,
                                   SceneNode target,
                                   IInputManager inputMgr,
                                   java.lang.String inputControllerName)
        Constructs a ThirdPersonCameraController that allows orbiting the specified camera around the specified target SceneNode using the controls provided by the specified IInputManager and input controller. The inputControllerName parameter must be the name of a recognized controller; controller names can be obtained from an IInputManager using a variety of methods.

        Parameters:
        cam - - the camera to control
        target - - the target node which the camera is to look at
        inputMgr - - the IInputManager which provides access to controllers
        inputControllerName - - the name of the controller containing the components which manipulate the third-person camera
        See Also:
        IInputManager, Controller

    • Method Detail

      • setMouseWheelSpeed

        public void setMouseWheelSpeed(float newSpeed)
        Sets the speed at which rotating the mouse wheel causes the camera to zoom in/out. The default value is 1.0. Setting a negative value reverses the direction of motion.
        Parameters:
        newSpeed - The new speed factor for the mouse wheel

      • update

        public void update(float time)
        Updates this ThirdPersonCameraController by determining the current target position, setting a new camera position based on the target position and the current azimuth, elevation, and distance values for the camera (that is, the current position of the camera relative to the target), and forcing the camera to look at the target node from its new position. This method should be called (directly or indirectly) once each time around the application's game loop.
        Parameters:
        time - - amount of time since last update, in msec (currently unused)

      • getCamera

        public ICamera getCamera()
        Returns the camera which this ThirdPersonCameraController is controlling.
        Returns:
        the camera being controlled

      • setCamera

        public void setCamera(ICamera cam)
        Sets the camera to be controlled by this ThirdPersonCameraController.
        Parameters:
        cam - The camera to be controlled

      • getWorldUpVec

        public graphicslib3D.Vector3D getWorldUpVec()
        Returns the direction of "up" in the world coordinate system.
        Returns:
        A Vector3D giving the world up direction

      • setWorldUpVec

        public void setWorldUpVec(graphicslib3D.Vector3D worldUpVec)
        Sets a new world up direction.
        Parameters:
        worldUpVec - the worldUpVec to set

      • getTargetPos

        public graphicslib3D.Point3D getTargetPos()
        Returns the position of the target (that is, the SceneNode which the camera being controlled looks at).
        Returns:
        the target position

      • setTargetPos

        public void setTargetPos(graphicslib3D.Point3D targetPos)
        Sets a new target position. Note that setting a target position is not the same as setting a new target.
        Parameters:
        targetPos - the new target position
        See Also:
        setTarget(SceneNode)

      • getTarget

        public SceneNode getTarget()
        Returns the SceneNode which is the current target of the camera (that is, the SceneNode that the camera looks at.
        Returns:
        - the target SceneNode

      • setTarget

        public void setTarget(SceneNode target)
        Causes the specified SceneNode to become the target of the camera being controlled -- meaning that the camera will subsequently always "look at" the specified SceneNode.
        Parameters:
        target - the SceneNode which is to become the new camera target

      • getTargetOffset

        public graphicslib3D.Vector3D getTargetOffset()
        Returns the target offset; that is, the offset amount in the world "up" direction above the target SceneNode which defines the point at which the camera looks.
        Returns:
        the target offset

      • setTargetOffset

        public void setTargetOffset(graphicslib3D.Vector3D targetOffset)
        Parameters:
        targetOffset - A Vector3D specifying the offset from the target SceneNode where the camera should point

      • getMaxDistance

        public float getMaxDistance()
        Returns the current maximum distance which the camera is allowed to be moved away from the target SceneNode.
        Returns:
        - the maximum distance the camera is allowed to be away from the target

      • setMaxDistance

        public void setMaxDistance(float maxDistance)
        Sets the maximum distance which the camera is allowed to be moved away from the target. maxDistance must be greater than or equal to minDistance, the minimum distance from the camera to the target; if the specified maxDistance is less than the current minDistance then calling this method has no effect.
        Parameters:
        maxDistance - - the maximum distance allowed between the camera and the target.
        See Also:
        setMinDistance(float)

      • getMinDistance

        public float getMinDistance()
        Returns the current minimum allowed distance between the camera and the target.
        Returns:
        the minimum distance the camera is allowed to be from the target

      • setMinDistance

        public void setMinDistance(float minDistance)
        Sets the minimum allowed distance between the camera and the target. If the specified minDistance is less than 0 or greater than the current maxDistance then this method has no effect.
        Parameters:
        minDistance - - the minimum allowed distance between the camera and the target
        See Also:
        setMaxDistance(float)

      • getDistance

        public float getDistance()
        Returns the current distance between the camera and the target.

      • setDistance

        public void setDistance(float distance)
        Sets the distance between the camera and the target; that is, moves the camera to be at the specified distance from the target. If the specified distance is greater than the current maximum distance or less than the current minimum distance, the corresponding maximum or minimum is used instead of the specified value.

      • getMaxElevationAngle

        public float getMaxElevationAngle()
        Returns the current maximum elevation angle (in degrees) which the camera is allowed to rotate "above" the target.

      • setMaxElevationAngle

        public void setMaxElevationAngle(float maxElevationDegrees)
        Sets the maximum elevation angle (in degrees) for the camera. If the specified maximum elevation angle is less than the current minimum elevation angle or is greater than 89 degrees, this method has no effect.

      • getMinElevationAngle

        public float getMinElevationAngle()
        Returns the current minimum elevation angle (in degrees) for the camera.

      • setMinElevationAngle

        public void setMinElevationAngle(float minElevationDegrees)
        Sets the minimum elevation angle (in degrees) for the camera. If the specified minimum elevation angle is greater than the current maximum elevation angle or is less than (that is, more negative than) -89 degrees, this method has no effect.

      • setSpeed

        public void setSpeed(float speed)
        Sets the speed at which mouse movement causes camera movement.
        Parameters:
        speed - - a multiplier for the amount of mouse movement

      • getSpeed

        public float getSpeed()
        Returns the mouse "speed factor"; that is, the multiplier which is used to control the amount by which mouse changes cause changes in camera movement.
        Returns:
        the current mouse speed multiplier
